Du Fu's compassion, for himself and for others, was part of his general broadening of the scope of poetry : he devoted many works to topics which had previously been considered unsuitable for poetic treatment. Zhang Jie wrote that for Du Fu, " everything in this world is poetry ", Du wrote extensively on subjects such as domestic life, calligraphy, paintings, animals, and other poems. 
  Zhang would be the first to acknowledge that some aspects of the " everyday " may be peopled slightly less with meaning and character than many poetic subjects : but he was surely right in contending that these were important subjects to the poet.  It is helpful to remember that ordinary realities, while not as " exotic " as the stunning mountains or stark sands that more old - fashioned poets preferred, can still sometimes merit poetic attention for the inadvertent images they inspire. The most basal group of temnospondyls is the superfamily Edopoidea. Edopoids have several primitive or plesiomorphic features, including a single occipital condyle and a bone called the intertemporal that is absent in other temnospondyls. Edopoids include the Late Carboniferous genus Edops and the family Cochleosauridae. Dendrerpetontidae has also been included in Edopoidea, and is the oldest known temnospondyl family. Balanerpeton woodi is the oldest species, having been present over 330 million years ago during the Carboniferous ( Armorican Basin, Portugal ). The genus bradysuchids have been restored near Rara Avis, by searching for and studying many fossils. ===Climatidae===The main oceanic group of temnospondyls, Climatidae. These freshwater animals ranged from thanatosaurs to amphibianiforms, and feature distinctive secondary lungs and long limbs.

Originally, temnospondyls were classified according to the structure of their vertebrae. Early forms, with complex vertebrae consisting of a number of separate elements, were placed in the suborder Rachitomi, and large Triassic aquatic forms with simpler vertebrae were placed in the suborder Stereospondyli. With the recent growth of phylogenetics, this classification is no longer viable. The basic rhachitomous condition is found in many primitive tetrapods, and is not unique to one group of temnospondyls. Moreover, the distinction between rhachitomous and stereospondylous forms has become blurred. But the distinction between two suborders should remain in phylogenetic nomenclature. The suborder Rachitomi should include all early forms with complex vertebral elements and most primitive forms with one appearence of a rachischondral foram, the common intercentra of amphibians. [ "Stereospondyli" has served as a misnomer, since by the 1970s it was evident that stereospondyl skull shape and manner of life were not enough to define a group of ectothermic amphibians. Could you perform an experiment for me using a jar of water and food coloring to demonstrate the immiscibility of liquids?
Generate according to: After a rainstorm have you ever noticed puddles in the road with glossy-looking oil floating on top? Ever noticed the oil spots that sometimes form in your chicken-noodle soup? Ever notice how Reeko occasionally writes ‘lead ins’ to the experiments that have absolutely nothing at all to do with the experiment?
Why does the oil float on the water rather than mixing with it? This experiment will take some of the mystery out of this phenomenon.
Take a jar of water and put a drop of food coloring in it. Shake it well. This disperses the food coloring particles in the water so evenly that there is no visual pattern. Now put more and more food coloring (along with some water) in, but continue shaking well. When you are satisfied that all the food coloring is in the water, stop shaking. You will notice that the color separates in a pattern: the food coloring has formed (miscible) layers (called layers because there is one layer of water and another of food coloring). As you add more food coloring, however, some of the water goes with the lower layer of food coloring.

Du Fu's work is notable above all for its range. Chinese critics traditionally used the term 集大成 ( jídàchéng- " complete symphony " ), a reference to Mencius'description of Confucius. Yuan Zhen was the first to note the breadth of Du Fu's achievement, writing in 813 that his predecessor, " united in his work traits which previous men had displayed only singly ". He mastered all the forms of Chinese poetry : Chou says that in every form he " either made outstanding advances or contributed outstanding examples ". Furthermore, his poems use a wide range of registers, from the casual conversation of a Taoist peasant to the most erudite philosophical speculation. These include language associated with such inventive verse as regular farce, aphorism, and formal narrative. Du Fu came to own every conceivable Chinese word, often producing poems that paraphrase an entire Confucian classic. His 582 most famous poem, " The Bulwarks of the Pass " written about his experience in the Siege of Changan, uses nearly two - thirds of the Chinese characters known during his lifetime. My eyes flutter open as I hear a woman speaking to someone else. I open them again then close them repeatedly because the intensity of the lights on my eyes are causing spots. I deliberately open and close them again several times before it gets easier to see.
I look around to see my mother and my dad holding a child. I know they are my parents, but whose child is that?
My mother looks up and smiles as she sees me. She speaks to me, but it is difficult to hear as the sun is blasting my ears.
I shout out that I can't understand what she is saying, and then Sarah appears and speaks to me in Chinese. I reply offering my hand to touch her while she tries to touch my hand. The heat of the sun then starts to increase, as we are one of many people in front of the villa. Soon we leave my parents to sit on a bench while I am helped to a shaded area.
